nd saw Tucson, whose looked agitated > To: nbwrpg@yahoogroups.com

Lessons to be Learned.
> 
> 
> > An insult to his logic was definitely a te=
st to Tucson's already short temper.  Yet he knew he had to keep that in ch=
eck if he was to keep his position.  He turns to Wheelie with a narrowed br=
ow.  Yet not one word is said.  He then raises it.
> > 
> > " Hmmmm... So t=
hat's how you see me?  If I'm not mistaken Wheelie I believe you have just =
crossed the line of insubordination.  I'm giving you a chance to be part of=
 the team but I see nothing in return on your part.  Well, care to explain =
to me the Autobot code of honor and what happens when a soldier behaves out=
 of line, going as far as insulting a Prime Officer?  You seem to be quite =
intelligent, go on, tell me."
> > 
> > Rattrap and Straight Shot look to Wh=
eelie in shock.
> > 
> > " Looks like a certain little go cart's in for som=
e serious discipline. "
> > 
> > Straight Shot swallows hard.
> > 
> > " Hi=
s voice, it sounds just like Ratchet's voice when he was ready ta lose it."=

> > 
> > Rattrap watches with amusement.
> > 
> > " Ooohhh so that's where=
 Tucson's temper comes from.  Yep Wheelie is in big trouble."
> > 
> > Tucs=
on eyes Wheelie with arms folded in his chest.  His stare indicative of Rat=
chet when he was ready to lose his temper.
> > 
> 
> At this point, Wheelie=
 stood up, "Yes, I say you are wrong.  There's no such thing as a space bri=
dge that strong.  You would simply see it from afar, with our own optics th=
e sensors abar.  You cannot remotely hide such a hting, in the technology o=
f our time or even that thing.  To do such a thing, to rip apart time, is s=
tupidly absurd, I call it this time.  So if you are going to say we should =
waste our time going after what does not exist, I say thee nay."
> 
> Wheel=
ie went on, "So, stop wasting oru time for such a stupid thing, or I will g=
o out on my own and bring.  Rodimus is my friend, I won't leave him alone t=
o face his end.  If you are goin to be a boron, then I shall call you a nim=
rod and boron."
> 
> Hissing, "Now, I would say you are wasting our time, o=
n pointless things that we needn't to whine.  So I say, I think you want my=
 friend dead today."
> 
> At the Laurel and Hardy back and forth of Rattrap=
 and Straight SHot, Wheelie just laughed, "And you bring up Ratchet?  Well =
he's dead.  MEgatron blew off his head.  And you seem to want Rodimus to en=
d the same way.  So I shall now not leave my friend astray."
> 
> And witho=
ut a further word, Wheelie transformed to his vehicle mode, and raced off!
=
> 
> OOC - This is how I see the character - at this point, he thinks it's =
utter nonsense to waste time looking for a Space Bridge that there's no evi=
dence of or anything remotely suggesting, based upon Tuscon having a 'hunch=
' so he's going insubordinate and off on his own.  TO him, a Space Bridge w=
ould e impossible to hdie (a la the third Transformers movie Dark of the Mo=
on), and so wasting time scanning for it is a fool's errand.  So he's going=
 off to 'look' for Rodimus on his own, unless stopped or otherwis einterfer=
ed with as he's afraid that Tuscon is purposefully stalling to prevent them=
 from going after Rodimus.  He respects Leo Prime, but he's friends with Ro=
rimus, and he has a very low regard for Tuscon, and at this point in his pr=
ocessor Tuscon deciding to check for something to him that has infinitesima=
l chances of having been done and stall a gridwide search is abaondment of =
his friend.  Anyways, wondrful posting and good luck!
>
